title: Why is ketchup so hard to pour? - George Zaidan

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the behavior of ketchup when poured from a bottle?

options.label: A
options.text: It pours like a liquid, similar to water.

options.label: B
options.text: It behaves like a solid and does not pour at all.

options.label: C
options.text: It exhibits Non-Newtonian behavior, changing its apparent thickness depending on the force applied.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a Newtonian fluid?
What happens to ketchup when a force above the threshold is applied?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes thicker and more solid-like.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes a thousand times thinner than before.

multiple-choice.question: Why does ketchup exhibit Non-Newtonian behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to the presence of xanthan gum.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the even distribution of tomato particles.

options.label: C
options.text: Due to the combination of tomato particles and liquid ingredients.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the shape of the ketchup bottle.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a weak force is applied to ketchup for a long time?

options.label: B
options.text: The ketchup becomes thicker and more solid-like.

options.label: C
options.text: The tomato particles slowly rearrange themselves, allowing the ketchup to flow.

options.label: D
options.text: The ketchup remains the same consistency.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of adding xanthan gum to ketchup?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the ketchup thinner and more pourable.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the ketchup thicker and more solid-like.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the ketchup's consistency.

options.label: D
options.text: It changes the flavor of the ketchup.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists recommend getting ketchup out of a bottle?

options.label: B
options.text: By applying a series of long, slow shakes.

options.label: C
options.text: By hitting the bottle once very hard.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of short, sharp shakes and a controlled pour.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to fluids that exhibit behavior similar to ketchup?
Which of the following substances is an example of a Non-Newtonian fluid that becomes thicker when force is applied?
Why is ketchup considered a complicated mixture from a physics perspective?

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the complex interactions between its ingredients.

title: The weird, wonderful world of bioluminescence - Edith Widder

multiple-choice.question: What is bioluminescence?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of animals to reflect light.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of animals to absorb light.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of animals to produce light.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of animals to refract light.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker study bioluminescence?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a rare phenomenon in the ocean.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a way to visualize and track pollution.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is critical to understanding life in the ocean.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the bioluminescent "burglar alarm" used by some animals?
What is the function of the light organ under the eye of the black dragon fish?
How do some animals, like the shrimp, use bioluminescence to defend themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: By releasing bioluminescent chemicals into the water.

options.label: B
options.text: By producing a bright flash of light.

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a cloud of ink.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "electronic jellyfish" used by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the behavior of deep-sea animals.

options.label: C
options.text: To mimic the bioluminescent displays of deep-sea animals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the response of the giant sixgill shark to the electronic jellyfish?

options.label: C
options.text: It tries to eat the jellyfish.

options.label: D
options.text: It swims away from the jellyfish.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pinwheel display used by the speaker?
What is the response of the Humboldt squid to the pinwheel display?

options.label: C
options.text: It tries to eat the display.

options.label: D
options.text: It swims away from the display.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker encourage people to take a dive in a submersible?

options.label: A
options.text: To see the bioluminescent displays of deep-sea animals.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the behavior of deep-sea animals.

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the ocean and its inhabitants.

multiple-choice.question: Why are there many carbon compounds?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon atoms form chains very easily, sometimes millions of atoms long.

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon atoms can only form one or two bonds.

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon atoms are only found in living organisms.

options.label: D
options.text: Carbon atoms are only found in non-living materials.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element that makes up the important parts of our brains?
What is the name of the discipline that studies the chemistry of carbon compounds?
What is the name of the form of carbon that is found in pencils?
What is the name of the new form of carbon that was discovered in the last 20 years, which is a single sheet of carbon atoms?
What is the structure of diamond, and what makes it strong?

options.label: A
options.text: Diamond has a tetrahedral structure, and its strength comes from the weak bonds between its carbon atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Diamond has a tetrahedral structure, and its strength comes from the strong bonds between its carbon atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Diamond has a hexagonal structure, and its strength comes from the weak bonds between its carbon atoms.

options.label: D
options.text: Diamond has a hexagonal structure, and its strength comes from the strong bonds between its carbon atoms.

multiple-choice.question: Why does diamond appear colorless?

options.label: A
options.text: Because its electrons are tightly bound and cannot change their energy state.

options.label: B
options.text: Because its electrons are loosely bound and can change their energy state.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it absorbs all wavelengths of visible light.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it reflects all wavelengths of visible light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the molecule that has 60 carbon atoms and is shaped like a soccer ball?
What is the name of the form of carbon that is made up of whole tubes of hexagons?
Why is graphene considered a material of the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is very thick and can only be used for a few applications.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is very thin and can be used for a wide range of applications, including electronics and carbon computers.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is very expensive and can only be used for a few applications.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is very cheap and can only be used for a few applications.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reactivity of white phosphorus?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not reactive at all.

options.label: C
options.text: It is very reactive, especially with oxygen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the structure of white phosphorus molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: They exist as single phosphorus atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: They exist as discrete molecules of two phosphorus atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: They exist as discrete molecules of four phosphorus atoms connected like a pyramid.

options.label: D
options.text: They exist as a long chain of phosphorus atoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of storing phosphorus under water?

options.label: B
options.text: To keep it away from light.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep the oxygen and atmosphere away.

options.label: D
options.text: To keep it away from other chemicals.

multiple-choice.question: Why is red phosphorus used in matches?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is not reactive at all.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is less reactive than white phosphorus.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is more expensive than white phosphorus.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would be too heavy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would be too expensive to produce.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The phosphorus reacts with oxygen and burns.

options.label: C
options.text: The phosphorus reacts with oxygen and produces a nice 'P' for phosphorus.

options.label: D
options.text: The phosphorus does not react with the paper.

multiple-choice.question: Why is phosphorus important inside the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a necessary element for life.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is used to produce ATP.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is used to produce energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is silicon commonly found in?

options.label: B
options.text: Compounds of silicon and another metal

options.label: C
options.text: Compounds of oxygen, silicon, and another metal

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to make construction materials

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to make automotive parts

options.label: B
options.text: A single crystal has a more uniform structure

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To increase the cost of production

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the yield of usable chips

options.label: C
options.text: To test the quality of the chips

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the efficiency of production

options.label: B
options.text: They are used for other purposes

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using a larger wafer to produce silicon chips?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the cost of production

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the yield of usable chips

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for more chips to be produced at once

options.label: D

options.text: Because it is a good conductor of heat

options.label: D

title: Nature's smallest factory: The Calvin cycle - Cathy Symington

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of energy for plants to produce sugars?

options.label: A

options.text: To break down glucose into carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: The synthesis of ATP from sunlight
